original_data.question: An 18-year-old male is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash and was ejected from the vehicle after collision. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6. He is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse of 130 bpm, and blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg. He is noted to have multiple ecchymoses over his body, as well as petechiae and purpura. He has a laceration over his clavicle that continues to bleed despite a pressure bandage. Radiographs of his lower extremity show multiple long bone fractures. Two large bore IV lines are placed, and the patient oozes from around the sites of venepuncture. Labs are notable for a WBC of 20,000/mm^3, Hb of 10.1g/dL, platelets of 48,000/mm^3, and prolongation of the PT and aPTT. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?

model_response:
The patient's presentation is consistent with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). DIC is a feared complication of severe trauma, sepsis, and certain malignancies. It is characterized by widespread activation of coagulation, leading to both thrombosis and hemorrhage. The consumption of coagulation factors and platelets leads to bleeding from venepuncture sites, as well as oozing from the skin. The laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with DIC, as the PT and aPTT are prolonged, and the platelet count is low. The other choices are unlikely to be the cause of this patient's presentation. Air embolization can occur in the setting of trauma, but it is unlikely to cause the skin findings seen in this patient. Tension pneumothorax and coagulopathy of trauma can both cause bleeding from venepuncture sites, but they would not cause the skin findings seen in this patient. Coagulopathy of trauma is unlikely to cause the low platelet count seen in this patient.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
an unforeseen and unplanned event or circumstance frequently causing loss or injury in any vehicle; this includes automobiles, trains, planes, motorcycles, boats, bicycles, etc.
A substance used as a medium for administration of a pharmaceutical.
An accident resulting from violent impact of a moving object; an brief event in which two or more bodies come together.

The relationship that links to a Transportation Act (target) from another Act (source) indicating that the subject of the source Act entered into the source Act by means of the target Transportation act.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A scale that assesses the response to stimuli in patients with craniocerebral injuries. The parameters are eye opening, motor response, and verbal response.
This gene plays a role in the detoxification of endogenous reactive oxygen species. It is also involved in drug and xenobiotic metabolism.
A table of data specifically regarding vitals.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
Extravasation of blood into the skin, resulting in a nonelevated, rounded or irregular, blue or purplish patch, larger than a petechia.

The human being as a non-anatomical and non-zoological entity. The emphasis is on the philosophical or artistic treatment of the human being, and includes lay and social attitudes toward the body in history. (From J. Cassedy, NLM History of Medicine Division)
Purple or red hemorrhagic pinpoint spots in the skin or mucous membranes.

Purplish or brownish red discoloration, easily visible through the epidermis, caused by hemorrhage into the tissues. When the size of the discolorization is >2-3 cm it is generally called Ecchymoses (ECCHYMOSIS).
Torn, ragged, mangled wounds.
Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
An elastic bandage is a device consisting of either a long flat strip or a tube of elasticized material that is used to support and compress a part of a patient's body.
An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
An increased tendency to fractures of the long bones (Mainly, the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, radius, and ulna). [HPO:curators]
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A position in relation to its surroundings.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
White blood cells. These include granular leukocytes (BASOPHILS; EOSINOPHILS; and NEUTROPHILS) as well as non-granular leukocytes (LYMPHOCYTES and MONOCYTES).

The oxygen-carrying proteins of ERYTHROCYTES. They are found in all vertebrates and some invertebrates. The number of globin subunits in the hemoglobin quaternary structure differs between species. Structures range from monomeric to a variety of multimeric arrangements.
Non-nucleated disk-shaped cells formed in the megakaryocyte and found in the blood of all mammals. They are mainly involved in blood coagulation.
Care provided patients requiring extraordinary therapeutic measures in order to sustain and prolong life.

A heavy, soft, whitish metal, resembling tin, with atomic number 78, atomic weight 195.084, symbol Pt. It is used in manufacturing equipment for laboratory and industrial use. It occurs as a black powder (platinum black) and as a spongy substance (spongy platinum) and may have been known in Pliny's time as "alutiae".

The time required for the appearance of FIBRIN strands following the mixing of PLASMA with phospholipid platelet substitute (e.g., crude cephalins, soybean phosphatides). It is a test of the intrinsic pathway (factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII) and the common pathway (fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V and X) of BLOOD COAGULATION. It is used as a screening test and to monitor HEPARIN therapy.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
To show or display; the act of presenting something to sight or view: how something looks.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
